Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Software Engineering and Service Composition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Texas Tech University Research Experiences for Undergraduates Site program provides opportunities for ten undergraduate students each summer to conduct research on two of the most crucial aspects of computing, software engineering and service composition. This REU Site project meets the needs for an undergraduate computing research environment in the Texas South Plains and contributes to producing graduate students in two essential sub-disciplines of computer science. The overall basis for this REU Site is for research efforts that improve the development of software and service-oriented systems in a wide variety of application domains. There are three major objectives for the proposed REU Site: increase the percentage of women and underrepresented minority students; improve the retention of computer science students; and increase those undergraduate students entering into graduate computing education degree programs.

These objectives are met through research that addresses a broad spectrum of means for improving software development. The projects address: software specification generation based on user input and output; construction of a self-managed embedded software system using software specifications; and dynamic techniques for service composition and recovery in a service-oriented environment. The undergraduate student research topics include language development, software tool design and implementation, application development in a variety of application domains to demonstrate applicability, and measurement of the improvements. The technical results of the research efforts with undergraduate students will be disseminated in a broad set of publications. The broadening participation aspects of the broader impacts will be in the women and underrepresented minority students that are recruited for the program, the achievement of success at conducting research, and then continuation on to graduate school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF REU Site program, hosted at Texas Tech University, focused on providing research opportunities to students in the areas of software engineering, service composition, robotics, cybersecurity, and computing education. Over a three-year period, the program provided summer support for 28 students, including seven women, three Hispanic students, and five African-American students. About half of the participants have been from Texas Tech University. Eight students have been from universities and colleges that do not provide graduate programs in computer science (Stonehill College, Samford University, California Baptist University, Union University, Trinity University, Swarthmore College, and Vassar College), thus providing research opportunities to students that would not normally have such opportunities within their home institutions.

 

Research in the area of software engineering addressed topics such as reverse engineering of programs to software specifications, automatic programming from specifications, design of embedded systems, self-managed software systems, anomaly detection in software components, and specifications for real-time, object-oriented systems. Service composition research centered around a technique known as assurance points for addressing data consistency in service composition, addressing concurrent execution, efficiency of checking invariant conditions, and formalization and verification of the assurance point technique. Research topics in the area of robotics addressed multi-agent collaboration, design of motion patterns for robot soccer, object tracking, context for robot vision, fault detection for robot application, and POMDPs and answer set programming for decision making. Cybersecurity research included hardware and software simulations of a smart grid home area network and event stream processing for intrusion detection. A computer science education research project also addressed the integration of robotics with the Alice graphical programming tool to create a new environment known as Dorothy, providing a graphical means of programming robots in a virtual environment and then seeing the enactment of the program on robots in the real-world.

 

Student research has resulted in 12 published papers as well as eight poster presentations.
